comments.content:
Local job eh Duncan?

I quite like them in that they’re sufficiently different from each other; IMHO, Stempel Garamond is the best of the Garamonds that actually carry the name. I can see from reading the first few lines why you picked Maple for the headings – it looks like a grotesque that’s been made with a pair of tin snips.

BTW, Bringhurst recommends pairing Syntax with Stempel Garamond (p.106, paragraph two, of the second edition of ’The Elements of Typographic Style’) but apparently the new Syntax Next is a _lot_ more calligraphic than the old cut.

Good luck with it.
Lovely. Syntax doesn’t look good anywhere anymore. There are so many better options.

Hmm, Maple with (Stempel) Garamond, i don’t think it works.

I would check out different Modern/Scotch Roman/Egyptienne.  
Something like Corona, Excelsior, New Caledonia, Bookman Old Style, the Century Faces, Bell MT, Hoefler Text (or something quiet like Times Ten or an elegant Baskerville).

T.

Not an obvious pairing, but then they aren’t directly paired in your sample, I mean if you were using Maple for an intro text paragraph or for tables, then I doubt they would work. In your example it works for me.  
Tim

I personally like the combination of Tribute with Maple. They both share a kind of over-the-top attitude for their genre (if that makes any sense). I’ve also wondered how Storm’s Hercules would look with Maple...
I agree with Addison’s description of Tribute and Maple, but I don’t think you want two fonts of this sort in one layout, unless the content calls for it. Your page looks great.
Ish. Is that what a lowercase a looks like in Maple? Pardon me, while I excuse myself.

good to hear conflicting arguments.

Yeah, go for it. If anything will work with Maple, Garamond will.

- Lex
Maple is such a friendly typeface. It isn’t as uptight as some of the other woody typefaces available. I think it adds character to the page and pulls Stempel up by the boot straps.
